doc.after: Rankin won back her House seat in 1940 at the age of 60, defeating the incumbent Jacob Thorkelson, an outspoken antisemite. She was appointed to the Committee on Public Lands and the Committee on Insular Affairs. Ongoing debate in Congress and throughout the country over potential U.S. involvement in World War II was silenced after the attack on Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941.[8]
